Metadata: Identification of a conserved antigenic domain in the major capsid protein of infectious pancreatic necrosis virus
NOAA Technical Reports NMFS 111, pp. 15-20, October 1992; Proceedings of the Nineteenth U.S.-Japan Meeting on Aquaculture, Ise, Mie Prefecture, Japan, October 29-30, 1990 Ralph S. Svrjcek (editor)
ORESU-​R-​92-​017; Oregon Agricultural Experiment Station Technical Paper No. 9327

Infectious pancreatic necrosis virus (IPNV) is a birnavirus that causes one of the most serious diseases in trout and salmon farms in North America, Europe, and Asia. It can also kill a number of nonsalmonid fish. Most IPNV isolates are closely related antigenically, yet they exhibit marked differences in host-range in-vivo and in-vitro, in pathogenicity, and in temperature of replication. This paper reviews recent efforts to unravel the mechanisms that biologically distinguish the different IPNV isolates by characterizing the immunoreactive regions of the major capsid protein of the Sp serotype of IPNV.
